south

xr mental health training for community leaders

  • topic: participatory design, xr
  • client: cuny
  • location: nyc
  • year: 2022

The main goal of the project is the development of an XR (extended reality) training tool that will effectively equip social services community leaders (from Community-Based Organizations connected to the Harlem Strong Collaborative) with new, practical skills needed to help their community members in identifying, understanding, and resolving mental health issues and needs.

Our plan is to match XR affordances for (psycho-)educational settings with evidence-based / informed mental health-related skills and training approaches based on existing literature, user research, and consultations with clinical experts. This list of potentially effective affordances will inform the development of a prototype for mental health training to then be evaluated by quantitative and qualitative methods.

We will start the project with user research to clarify details of who exactly we’re designing for, what their needs are, and if there are any particular situations or conditions that could benefit greatly from augmented, on-demand training.

After a prototyping phase we will develop the XR experience in tandem with the training curricula design development, ideally with collaborative insights from social services workers and/or mental health providers, learning along the way which principles and practices translate well to AR, as validated by user testing.

Finally, we’ll test with surveys and quantitative metrics to see if the training is effective and map out a plan to publish findings to inspire further research and funding. We will conclude with discussions on how to scale the XR training experiences to turn them into working components for deployment.
